sen.j: 「無門関」第2則の「百丈野狐」の公案には、前世に百丈山にいた老人が、かつて覚った者は「因果に落ちない」と言い、「空」の境涯のみを持ち上げて因果の理法を無視したが為に、五百生の間、野狐身の畜生道に堕したという話がある。
sen.e: In koan (small presentations of the nature of ultimate reality, usually presented as a paradox) in 'Hyakujonoyako,' the second rule of 'Mumonkan,' there is a story about an old man who lived in Hyakujo-san Mountain in previous life, claiming that one who have reached enlightenment before never 'fall into inga (cause and effect)' again, ignored the principle of inga by concentrating in mental state of 'ku' (emptiness) only, resulting in falling into chikushodo (the realm of animals) as yako for five-hundred lifetimes.

In a koan (a Zen question for use in meditation) within the 'Hyakujonoyako,' the second rule of 'Mumonkan,' there is a story about an old man who lived in Mt. Hyakujo in a previous life who claims that those who have once reached enlightenment do not 'fall into inga (cause and effect; karma).' Instead, by concentrating only on a state of "ku" (emptiness) and ignoring the principle of inga, they fall into a state of chikushodo (the realm of animals) as a yako for five-hundred lifetimes.
sen.cmt: "(small presentations of the nature of ultimate reality, usually presented as a paradox)" is long and wordy, so I changed it to be more concise; Hyakujo-san Mountain→Mt. Hyakujo; added "karma" to "cause and effect" for a clearer description; changed this into two sentences as I could not comfortably keep it as one
sen.e: In a koan (a Zen question for use in meditation) within the 'Hyakujonoyako,' the second rule of 'Mumonkan,' there is a story about an old man who lived in Mt. Hyakujo in a previous life who claims that those who have once reached enlightenment do not 'fall into inga (cause and effect; karma).' Instead, by concentrating only on a state of 'ku' (emptiness) and ignoring the principle of inga, they fall into a state of chikushodo (the realm of animals) as a yako for five-hundred lifetimes.
sen.cmt: kuダブルクォーテーションをシングルクォーテーションに修正しました。

sen.j: この話からいったんの「空」の無相の境涯に捉われて、真に妙有・妙用（みょうう・みょうゆう）の境地に達しないのに、自ら覚り終ったとする独り善がりの増上慢（ぞうじょうまん）の禅をたとえて言ったものである。
sen.e: In this story, a caution is made with an example about self-satisfactory conceited zen, that by being seized to mental state of 'ku,' sometimes one can be mistaken to have reached enlightenment, even though he hasn't reached the state of true myou myoyu.
sen.cmt: 妙有・妙用→定訳不明です
sen.e: In this story, a caution is made through an example of self-satisfactory conceited zen, that by being caught in a mental state of 'ku,' it is possible to mistake that one has reached enlightenment, even though they have not reached the state of true myou myoyu.
sen.cmt: seized→caught; hasn't→have not; I also do no know what to do about 妙有・妙用（みょうう・みょうゆう）
sen.e: In this story, a caution is made through an example of self-satisfactory conceited zen, that by being caught in a mental state of 'ku,' it is possible to mistake that one has reached enlightenment, even though they have not reached the state of true myou (mysterious or wondrous manifestations) and myoyu (mysterious influence; mysterious effect).
sen.cmt: myou に (mysterious or wondrous manifestations)、myoyu に (mysterious influence; mysterious effect) をそれぞれ追記しました。用語集には意味が掲載されていませんでしたが、妙有（←「真空妙有」）、妙用と各々検索してみると定訳が見つかりました。（用語集に登録済みです）読み方は複数あるようですが、字と意味は同じようですので、読みは原文に従い、意味のみを追記しました。

sen.j: なお、日蓮は四箇格言の一つで「禅天魔」と、禅宗を厳しく批判した。

sen.j: その理由を教外別伝・不立文字で経典に依らないからとしているが、おそらく野狐禅に陥るという一面を取り上げて批判したものと考えられる。
sen.e: Nichiren said that the reason for the criticism is because that Zen sect is not based on Buddhist scripture and have principle of kyouge-betsuden and furyu-monji (both meaning that the principle is inside people's heart, not on scriptures), but it is believed that he made criticism by picking up the side of Zen sect that a person might fall into yakozen.

Nichiren said that the reason for the criticism was due to the Zen sect not being based on Buddhist scriptures and having the principles of kyouge-betsuden and furyu-monji (both meaning that the principles are inside one's heart, not on scriptures), but it is believed that his criticism was on the aspect of a person possibly falling into yakozen.
